lessons.title: Lesson 1: What is a Fraction?
lessons.goal: Understand numerator, denominator, and the meaning of a fraction.

questions.question: Which part of 3/4 is the numerator? (3 or 4)
questions.correct_feedback: ✅ Correct — numerator is the top number showing parts taken.
questions.incorrect_feedback: ❌ The numerator is the top number — it shows how many parts are taken.
questions.explanation: A fraction has two parts: the numerator (top) and the denominator (bottom). The numerator tells you how many parts we have.

questions.question: A pizza is cut into 8 slices. You eat 3 slices. Write the fraction eaten.
questions.correct_feedback: ✅ Correct — 3/8 means 3 out of 8 equal parts.
questions.incorrect_feedback: ❌ The numerator is 3 (slices eaten) and denominator is 8 (total slices).
questions.explanation: Fractions compare parts to the whole. Here, “3” is parts eaten, “8” is total parts.

questions.question: Match the fraction to its meaning: 1/2 → half, 3/4 → three quarters, 5/5 → whole
questions.correct_feedback: ✅ Well done — these are common fractions.
questions.incorrect_feedback: ❌ Remember: 1/2 means half, 3/4 means three of four parts, 5/5 means all parts taken.
questions.explanation: Fractions are just another way of saying “part of something” — match them to their everyday meaning.

lessons.title: Lesson 2: Comparing Fractions
lessons.goal: Compare fractions with same and different denominators.

questions.question: Which is greater: 3/4 or 2/4?
questions.correct_feedback: ✅ Correct — more parts taken means a larger fraction when denominators match.
questions.incorrect_feedback: ❌ If denominators match, compare numerators — higher numerator wins.
questions.explanation: When denominators match, compare numerators directly.

questions.question: Arrange from smallest to largest: 1/2, 1/4, 3/4
questions.explanation: One way to compare fractions is to convert them to decimals or use visual models.

questions.question: Which is greater: 2/3 or 3/5?
questions.incorrect_feedback: ❌ Convert or cross-multiply to compare fractions with different denominators.
questions.explanation: To compare 2/3 and 3/5, cross-multiply: 2×5=10, 3×3=9 — since 10>9, 2/3 is bigger.

lessons.title: Lesson 3: Adding Fractions (Same Denominator)
lessons.goal: Add fractions with the same denominator.

questions.incorrect_feedback: ❌ Add numerators when denominators match — 2+3=5, denominator stays the same.
questions.explanation: If denominators are the same, add the numerators and keep the denominator.

questions.question: Match the problem to the answer: 1/5+2/5 → 3/5, 4/9+2/9 → 6/9
questions.correct_feedback: ✅ Yes — denominators match, so you add tops only.
questions.incorrect_feedback: ❌ Remember: only add numerators for same-denominator fractions.
questions.explanation: The bottom number shows part size, which doesn’t change when adding same-sized parts.

questions.question: A jug has 2/6 litre of water. You add 1/6 litre. How much now?
questions.incorrect_feedback: ❌ You add the parts — 2+1=3, denominator stays as 6.
questions.explanation: Visualise the jug split into 6 equal parts — you add the filled parts together.

lessons.title: Lesson 4: Adding Fractions (Different Denominator)
lessons.goal: Add fractions with different denominators by finding common denominator.

questions.explanation: To add fractions with different denominators, make the bottoms match, then add tops.

questions.question: Order the steps: (1) Find LCM of denominators, (2) Convert fractions, (3) Add numerators
questions.incorrect_feedback: ❌ Check the order — first match denominators.
questions.explanation: Adding fractions works best when you follow a fixed sequence — LCM → convert → add.

questions.incorrect_feedback: ❌ Find common denominator first before adding.
questions.explanation: Here, 2/3 = 4/6, 3/6 stays as is, total is 7/6.

lessons.title: Lesson 5: Fractions in Real Life
lessons.goal: Apply fraction skills to everyday problems.

questions.question: A recipe needs 3/4 cup sugar. You have 1/2 cup. How much more do you need?
questions.explanation: To find how much more, subtract what you have from what you need.

questions.question: You ran 2/5 of a race in the morning and 1/5 in the afternoon. How much in total?
questions.explanation: Fractions with same denominator just add up top numbers.

questions.question: A shop is giving 1/3 off all items. If a jacket costs $90, how much is the discount?
questions.explanation: Multiply the whole by the fraction to find the discount.
